Legal_Issue: Whether Section 22 of the Trademarks Act can be used as a ground for opposition in trademark registration proceedings
Procedural_Stage: Judicial Review of Opposition Board Decision
Decision_Outcome: Tribunal's decision set aside, case referred back for reconsideration
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant must be satisfied they are entitled to use the trademark under Section 30(i)
Legal_Rule: Section 38(2)(a) permits opposition based on non-compliance with Section 30(i); Section 22 prohibits use of trademarks likely to depreciate goodwill
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on legal interpretation
Procedural_Issue: Amendment of opposition statement to include new legal ground
Grounds_for_Claim: Parmalat claimed Sysco's 'BLACK DIAMOND' mark would depreciate its goodwill under Section 22
Review_Standard: Error of law or misinterpretation of statutory provisions
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Tribunal erred by misstating issue and ignoring jurisprudence
Court_Result: Judicial review allowed, decision set aside, matter referred back
Defendant_Response: Sysco opposed amendment of Parmalatâ€™s grounds; tribunal initially rejected inclusion of Section 22
Remedy_Requested: Inclusion of Section 22 as opposition ground
Outcome: Claim not finally resolved; remanded for reconsideration
Remedy_Sought: Set aside tribunal decision, refer back for reconsideration
Resolution_Mechanism: Judicial review followed by administrative reconsideration
Legal_Provision: Section 22, Section 30(i), Section 38(2)(a) of the Trademarks Act
Claimant_Status: Parmalat as opponent of trademark application
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Section 22 not listed as standalone ground under Section 38(2)
Applicable_Process: Trademark opposition and judicial review process
Outcome_of_Review: In favor of Parmalat on procedural grounds
Pending_Relief_or_Application: Reconsideration of opposition including Section 22 argument
